div.p: A TREATISE OF THE Nature and U≈øe Of the Bitter Purging Salt Contain'd in EPSOM, And ≈øuch other VVATERS.
By NEHEMIAH GREW, M. D. Fellow of the College of PHYSICIANS, and of the ROYAL SOCIETY.
LONDON, Printed in the Year 1697.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THat this Salt is made and ≈øold in greater or le≈ø≈øer Quantities, by Francis Moult Chymi≈øt, at the Sign of Glaubers-Head in Watling-Street;
And this Tran≈ølation at no other Place.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: THE Rea≈øon of my publi≈øhing this Book in Engli≈øh is, the general U≈øe I ob≈øerve to be made of the Bitter Purging Salt in this Town and el≈øewhere, by all ≈øorts of Per≈øons, and that promi≈øcuou≈øly, in all Ca≈øes, as Peoples Fancies or Humours prompt 'em, without any Advice beyond Publick Fame, or the good Woman that la≈øt vi≈øited.

The Sellers of this Salt are likewi≈øe ≈øuch as u≈øe to di≈øpo≈øe of other Catholick or Univer≈øal Medicines, who neither know how to direct the Buyer, nor care what becomes of the Taker, ≈øo as they attain their End, their part of the Profit. There is indeed this difference; That other Medicines that have grown Popular were always u≈øher'd out with printed Directions, or Certificates of it's Virtues and numberle≈øs Cures, as Daffy's Elixir, Spirit of Scurvy-Gra≈øs, Atkins's Oil for the Gout, &c. Nay, the very Di≈øciples of
Ponteus afford for publick Benefit a printed Encomium for a Voucher to the Twelve-Penny Packet. This I thought ≈øufficient to Vindicate my Tran≈ølation of Dr. Grew's Nature & U≈øe of the Bitter Purging Salt, which I intend to give to tho≈øe who buy any quantities of the Salt. And I'd have the Reader take notice, That this is no Quack-Bill, no boa≈øting Rhodomontado of any Ignorant Pretender, no guilded Bu≈øh to ≈øet off bad Wine, but the Ob≈øervations of an Ingenious Phy≈øician, Fellow of both Societies, and publi≈øh'd by him in Latin, for the Information of the Practicers of Phy≈øick, and for no Private Intere≈øt or Profit. But, I can ≈øcarce believe the Doctor ever fore≈øaw the Con≈øequence of his Commendations wou'd be the pu≈øhing every Body upon the U≈øe of it Hand over Head; therefore I doubt not his Pardon for my Tran≈ølating it without his Knowledge, my De≈øign being not to di≈øcover the ≈øecret Method of its Preparation, but to prevent by the≈øe Directions the Mi≈øchiefs he tells us may en≈øue the Abu≈øe of ≈øo good a Medicine. Farewell.

div.head: Part the Fir≈øt. OF THE NATURE OF THE Bitter Purging Salt.
CHAP. I. How the bitter Purging Waters were fir≈øt Di≈øcovered.
div.p: THE Mineral Waters ari≈øing near Ep≈øom in Surrey, the chief of all the bitter Purging Waters, were found out by a Country Man, in or about the Year 1620.
For near, the fir≈øt Ten Years, none but the Country People made u≈øe of them, and they only to wa≈øh External Ulcers.

Afterwards the Lord Dudley North, Father to Francis the late Lord-Keeper, labouring under a Melancholy Di≈øpo≈øition, for which he had formerly Drank the Spaw-Waters in Germany, was re≈øolv'd to try the Vertue of the≈øe Ep≈øom Waters flattering him≈øelf (I ≈øuppo≈øe) that he had found Chalybeate-Waters at his own Door.

However, tho' they an≈øwer'd not his de≈øire and expectation as to their Nature, yet he did not repent of his Experiment, but from that time drank the≈øe Purging Waters, as a Medicine ≈øent from Heaven, with abundance of ≈øucce≈øs.

Many others, encouraged by his Example, try'd the operation of the≈øe Waters; and among≈øt the fir≈øt, Maria de Medicis, Mother to the Wife of King Charles I. the Right Honourable George Lord Goring, Earl of Norwich, and many other Per≈øons of Quality.

The≈øe, and all others, who drank the Ep≈øom-Waters, came not for Plea≈øure but Health, and therefore always con≈øulted their own, or ≈øome Neighboring Phy≈øician, for the Rules they were to ob≈øerve.

In a little while Phy≈øicians came of their own accord to the≈øe Waters by who≈øe Authority they acquir'd ≈øo great a Reputation, that 2000 Per≈øons have been there
in one Day, to drink or divert them≈øelves.
About 30 Years ≈øince, many of the Inhabitants of London, who≈øe Bu≈øine≈øs or Poverty ob≈øtructed their going to Ep≈øom, had the Waters ≈øent to them.
Thus the Ice being broke, others brought great quantities to Town, which they ≈øold as well to Sick Per≈øons as Apothecaries, and continue ≈øtill to do ≈øo.

No wonder then that ≈øo few ≈øick People go to the≈øe Waters, 'tis not that the Modern Phy≈øicians e≈øteem them le≈øs, but becau≈øe the Numbers of ≈øuch as Drink at home, and at other Wells of the ≈øame Nature, do every Day mightily encrea≈øe.

For a few Years after the Di≈øcovery of the Ep≈øom-Waters was publi≈øh'd, others of the ≈øame ≈øort (found out by Enquiry or Chance) grew into tolerable Repute and U≈øe. The Names of the Principal are,
Barnet in Hertford≈øhire.
North-Hall in Hertford≈øhire.
Acton in Middle≈øex.
Cobham in Surrey.
Dullidge in Surrey.
Strettham in Kent.

Be≈øides the≈øe, the Curious and Inqui≈øitive may di≈øcover very many more to us unknown, e≈øpecially if they take along with
them this Direction, that ≈øweet Waters generally ari≈øe from the tops of Hills, but the≈øe from the Bottoms.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Nature of the Bitter Purging Waters.
div.p: THe≈øe Waters have no ta≈øte, but a moderate bitterne≈øs, which is very ≈øen≈øible.

Some that have Travelled into Syria and Egypt, mention bitter Waters in tho≈øe Countries; and St. James, in his Epi≈øtle, takes notice of ≈øweet and bitter Waters, as very common things in the Ea≈øtern Parts; all which bitter Waters, 'tis probable, are of this ≈øort.
The≈øe Fountains are not of an equal Strength nor Vertue, but ≈øome are much ≈øtronger than others; with the ≈øtronge≈øt Dullidge is ju≈øtly reckon'd with the gentler Ep≈øom.

The≈øe Waters in their Springs are without ≈ømell, but kept ≈øome Days or Weeks in Ve≈ø≈øels clo≈øe ≈øtopp'd, they putrifie and ≈øtink, e≈øpecially in Summer time; which will happen to all Waters, and ≈øometimes al≈øo to the cleare≈øt Spring Water, as we
are told by tho≈øe that Sail near the Equator.
Pour a little of this Water to Sirrup of Violets, and 'twill remain blue and unchang'd, as if 'twere mix'd with common Spring-water.

By the adding Lime water, it gives a whiti≈øh Muddy colour, as if ≈øome drops of Milk were mix'd with it, and the white parts will, in about an hours time, ≈øub≈øide in the form of a cloudy curdling, produc'd from the Union of the chalky Lexivial, and the acidity of the Cathartick Salts.
All the≈øe Waters will curdle Milk, if it be added to them when they are hot, or boiling, but not at all if mix'd when they are cold.

The Waters of any of the≈øe Wells, evaporated in a glazed Earthen, or any other proper Ve≈ø≈øel, will yield a kind of a Cream a top, and a ≈øediment at the bottom of the Ve≈ø≈øel, of both together, 6, 8, or 10 Drams from a Gallon.

This Cream is of an A≈øh colour, Stony ≈øub≈øtance, and re≈øembles Plai≈øter, but certainly not at all Lixivial, for every one knows that the Lapis Calcarius, or Lime-Stone, calcin'd, altho' actually cold, will grow very hot by pouring Water upon them, and emit a very great and thick
fume, and that apply'd to any part of the Body 'twill burn. Therefore Chirurgeons u≈øe it for a Potential Cautery; but the fore-mentioned Cream calcin'd in a Crucible, and Water pour'd upon it, cau≈øes neither ≈ømoak nor heat, nor does it acquire any the lea≈øt Pungency.

Sometimes, as in Acton-Waters, the thin Minute Particles of which it con≈øi≈øts Will be very re≈øplendent and brittle, and wholly in≈øipid, tho' Calcin'd as afore≈øaid, yet by the pouring on any acid Liquor, chiefly by Spirit of Nitre, an Ebullition, with a ≈øen≈øible heat, will be excited.

The le≈ø≈øer part of this Sediment is like in ≈øub≈øtance to the before-de≈øcrib'd Cream; the remainder is purely Saline, but compounded of two kinds of Salts, one a Muriatick or Sea-Salt, the other a Salt proper or ≈øpecial to the≈øe Waters, who≈øe Nature and Vertues I here de≈øign to treat of.
In Ep≈øom-Waters, the Muriatick Salt is about the 20th part of the whole Saline Compo≈øition; it is ≈øomething more in Dullidge, and in mo≈øt of the fore-mentioned Springs.

In its biting Ta≈øt, as well as in the Figure of its Chry≈øtals, 'tis not unlike Common Salt; whence it is that Waters, in which there is le≈øs of this Muriatick Salt, purge not ≈øo ≈øtrongly as others.

The other Salt, as we have ≈øaid before, is the proper, or peculiar Salt of the Purging Waters; 'tis made after the ≈øame manner as all Lixivial Salts, viz. by Evaporating, Filtring, and Chry≈øtalizing, Calcination only excepted. In this Preparation, the Earthy or Plai≈øtery part, is fir≈øt to be ≈øeparated from the Saline; then the Muriatick Salt, and a yellow and thick Liquor from the proper Salt of the Waters.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Nature of the Bitter Salt, peculiar to the Purging Waters.
div.p: THis Salt, if it be rightly prepar'd, is of a delicate whitene≈øs equal to new fall'n Snow.
This bitter Salt is much more evident in the Salt it ≈øelf, in a dry Form, than in the Water, and ≈ømites the Tongue with a very penetrating Pungency, but without any Acrimony.

If you di≈ø≈øolve a Dram of this Salt in a Pint of Common Water, which is its Natural proportion, 'twill have the ≈øame property of curdling Milk, and be ennobled with the ≈øame bitter Ta≈øt and Purging Vertue peculiar to its Mineral Water.

And therefore 'tis not improperly di≈øtingui≈øh'd
from the Sal Mirabilis, (made of Oil of Vitriol, and Common Salt) and from all other Salts, by the Name of the Bitter Purging Salt.

This bitter Purging Salt, from the different manner of evaporating its Water, or degree of Cold, to which 'tis afterwards expo≈øed, and other circum≈øtances, will ≈øhoot into Cry≈øtals of a greater or le≈ø≈øer Magnitude. But let the Dimen≈øions be what they will, the Figure is the ≈øame; for mo≈øt of their Cry≈øtals, if they ≈øhoot not too thick, are ≈ømall rectangular Pri≈øms, with four parallel ≈øides; the two oppo≈øite ≈øides ≈øomething flatter than the other. Sometimes they have two more ≈øides, and are Sexangular; but the≈øe are ≈øo ≈ømall that the naked Eye can hardly di≈øcover 'em.

Their length is about half an Inch, but their thickne≈øs not above a fith, ≈øixth or ≈øeventh part of their length; their Ba≈øis, a lump of the ≈øame; the Summit very different, having ≈øometimes three, but for the mo≈øt part four ≈øloping Plains, and with the fore-mention'd parallel ≈øides make obtu≈øe Angles, or pointed, or oftener ≈øharpned, like a Pen Knife: One of the ≈øloping Plains is generally bigger than the other three taken together, and of a
Pentangular or Sexangular Figure; the oppo≈øite to this Quadrangular or Pentangular; the other two Triangular and le≈øs; the la≈øt, ≈øometimes invi≈øible, without a Micro≈øcope.
The≈øe Cri≈øtals, in their Oblong Figure, do mo≈øt re≈øemble Salt-Petre; in their Rectangular they come neare≈øt to Sea-Salt.

This bitter Salt, di≈ø≈øolv'd in common Water, and ≈øtanding ≈øome Days in a Gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øel, ≈øhoots into Branches like little Trees round the ≈øides of the Gla≈øs: To the producing this Figure, the before-de≈øcrib'd Cri≈øtals of this Salt and of Sal Nitre (the points of which are terminated ≈øometimes into Right, ≈øometimes into Acute Angles) are very proper; the ≈øloping Plain of one Cri≈øtal joyning to the parallel Plain of the others. Which I have al≈øo demon≈øtrated to be done in the Generation of Leaves, by the Figure of their proper Salts. Plant. Ang. 9. lib. 4. p. 1. c. ult.

Where note by the way, That in that Di≈øcour≈øe I have ≈øet down the Figures of Sal Nitri and other Salts, not altogether as they appear to us, but, probably, as they do exi≈øt in the Plants them≈øelves.

Five Drams of this bitter Purging Salt, mixt in a Vial with half an Ounce of
common Water; and ≈øhaken together, by that Agitation only and the gentle Heat of the Hand in Winter, will all pre≈øently di≈ø≈øolve, except a few Grains; by which you ob≈øerve it to be more di≈ø≈øolvable than any other Salt.
'Tis di≈øtingui≈øh'd al≈øo by its Specifick Gravity from all other Salts; 'tis heavier than Allom, lighter than common Salt, and than Nitre, as we ≈øhall hereafter prove in the fifth Chapter.
A di≈ø≈øolution of this Salt, and Salt of Tartar, and any other Urinous or Lixivial Salt, will generate a white Coagulum, or a Nuetral Salt, of the ta≈øte of neither, but ≈øomething Styptick.
Strong and new Oil of Vitriol, poured upon this Salt, will cau≈øe a moderate Ebullition; from whence we may conclude it to be of an Alkaline Principle, and in ≈øome manner Lixivial.
But if you add any other Liquor that I know of, either Acid or Alkali, to this Salt, 'twill neither ferment nor grow hot.
This Salt in a Crucible, with a ≈øtrong fire, will melt and ≈øwell like Allom into a white Porous and boiling Calx.

But this Calx will (except about a 40th part of the whole) di≈ø≈øolve in a ≈øufficient quantity of common Water, which the
Lapis Calcarius, or Lime-Stone, will not.

This Calx, in a Crucible, with a vehement fire for an hour, will be as hard as Alaba≈øter, nor will it afterwards be ≈øoftned by the Air: Much otherwi≈øe 'tis with the Lime-Stone, which Calcin'd, and expos'd to the Air, falls to Powder.
Altho' by this Calcination it lo≈øes ≈øome part of its weight, yet its bitterne≈øs continues, and is rather increas'd.

The Calx of the bitter Purging Salt, by the affu≈øion of Spirit of Salt, or any other Acid, will pre≈øently ferment, which is more or le≈øs con≈øpicuous according to the ≈øtrength of the afore≈øaid Spirit; from whence al≈øo we may allow it to be in ≈øome ≈øort Lixivial.

From a Pound of this Salt Di≈øtill'd in a Gla≈øs Retort well Luted, with a Rever-beratory Fire, you'll have in the Receiver a little above half a pound of an Acid Spirit in ≈ømell and ta≈øt, every way equal to common Spirit of Salt.
Oil of Vitriol pour'd upon common Spirit of Salt, yields a dark and ≈ømoaky Vapour, which will likewi≈øe happen, if you drop the ≈øame Oil very ≈øtrong into the Spirit of the Purging Salt.

'Tis very well known, that all the Chalybeate
Waters will change to a Purple, by the addition of Galls, as will White-wine Vinegar, tho' more ob≈øcurely; but the infu≈øion of Galls will be in no wi≈øe alter'd by the Spirit of the Purging Salt, tho' an Acid, nor by the Spirit of üúç, or Oil of Vitriol, from whence, as well as many other ways, the different Nature of the≈øe, and other Acids, may be ≈øhown.

I took 8 Gla≈øs Bottles of River-Water, and with ≈øome drops of Sirrup of Violets colour'd them all blue alike; one of which I let ≈øtand without any thing el≈øe added to it. To a 2d I put a little Sal Nitri; to a third ≈øome of the bitter Purging Salt; to a fourth a little Lime-Water; to the fifth a di≈ø≈øolution of the Calx of the Purging Salt; to the ≈øixth an infu≈øion of white Tartar; to the ≈øeventh the Di≈øtill'd Spirit of the Purging Salt; to the la≈øt, a little of both Lime-Water and the Purging Salt.
In the three fir≈øt, the Cerulous colour remain'd only a little faded.
In the 4th and 5th, the Cerulous colour was converted to a manife≈øt Green; in the former turbid and paler, in the latter like a Smarag'd, very deep and clear.
In the 6th and 7th it turn'd purple; in the fir≈øt ob≈øcure, but the latter was like a true Amethy≈øt.
The green colour, in the 4th and 5th, vani≈øh'd in about 3 hours, but the 5th was much deeper, and more durable.

From this manifold Experiment we may ob≈øerve, that as Nitre, although by accen≈øion it will yield a fix'd Lixivial Salt, and by Di≈øtillation an Acid Spirit, yet has neither a Lixivial, nor Acid ta≈øt, therefore gives neither green nor purple colour to the Sirrup; ≈øo we may conclude the Purging bitter Salt to con≈øi≈øt of like principles, that is not ≈øolely Acid, but al≈øo Alkalious, and a little Lixivial.

But it may be evidently demon≈øtrated, that its principles do partake of both, by the acidity of its Spirit, and the green colour; its Calx gives Sirrup of Violets like Aqua Calcis, and other Lixivial Liquors.

In the la≈øt Bottle the colour was deeper and more durable, by the combination or union of the twofold Alkalious Salt, the bitter Purging Salt, and the Calcarious, as Ink is made by the union of two A≈øtringents.

And 'tis very plain, that the exi≈øtence of the≈øe Salts, and their efficacy in altering Colours, depends not on the fire, becau≈øe the infu≈øion of white Tartar will, like the Spirit of the Purging Salt, die the Sirrup of a purple colour.
La≈øtly, Take notice that I call the Alkaline Principle in this Purging Salt potentially, and after a ≈øort Lixivial.

For, as we have ob≈øerv'd in this Chapter, you can perceive no Lixivial ta≈øt even in the Calx of this Salt, which does not hinder, but that an Alkaline Principle may be in this Salt, as appears from the fore cited Experiments, tho' it has never endured the fire, but after Calcination it is prov'd to be I know not how Lixivial.

I call it Lixivial, tho that, nor any other Name in U≈øe that I know of, is ju≈øtly adapted to its Nature, for there is a want of proper Words to expre≈øs our meanings in nothing ≈øo much as in Philo≈øophy, ≈øuch as ≈øhould lead us through the Foot≈øteps of Nature, and Intelligibly expre≈øs its admirable variety.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the difference between the bitter Purging Salt, Allom, and the Muriatick Salt.
div.p: FRom the fore-cited Experiments, and tho≈øe we ≈øhall now mention rightly under≈øtood and compar'd, 'twill evidently appear that the Purging bitter Salt, tho' it may have ≈øome Qualities common to other Salts, does differ in its Nature and Species from all other Salts.

Very many have confidently affirm'd it to proceed from an Aluminous Minera, but incon≈øiderately, for from whence is it they prove it, but becau≈øe they coagulate Milk, which is no rea≈øon at all, for by the ≈øame ridiculous Argument, Vinegar, Wine, Beer, and whatever curdles Milk, mu≈øt be Aluminous.

Nor does it appear from hence, that like Allom, when melting, it ≈øwells and ri≈øes in bubbles, for Borax melted will have the ≈øame Elevation, but Borax does not curdle Milk, therefore is not Aluminous, nor from thence can the bitter Purging Salt be ≈øo.

Moreover, from an Ounce of Allom calcin'd half an hour in a Crucible, there will remain half an Ounce of Calx. To this pour a ≈øufficient quantity of common Water to di≈ø≈øolve the Saline parts, and there will remain about 52 Grains of an in≈øipid and ≈øimple Earth at the bottom of the Ve≈ø≈øel, which is ≈øix times as much as the like quantity of the Calx of the bitter Salt will leave behind it.

Nor is the Spirit of Allom Di≈øtill'd with a ≈øtrong Fire any thing like the Spirit of this Salt, for the fir≈øt has a greater acrimony, and much le≈øs grateful ta≈øt; and which is worth Ob≈øervation, a Fetid
≈ømell very like to the Spirit or Ga≈øs of Sulphure.

The ta≈øt likewi≈øe of this bitter Purging Salt and Allom is ≈øo different, that nothing can be more; for that of Allom is au≈øtere and has no bitterne≈øs, the other no manner of au≈øterity but wholly bitter.

Be≈øides, they are evidently di≈øtingui≈øh'd by their Natural Figures for the Chry≈øtals of Allom, the Factitious at lea≈øt con≈øidering its Altitude are ≈øomething flatti≈øh, and con≈øi≈øt of 8 Planes; two, viz. tho≈øe at top and bottom, Sexangular and Parallel: The greater and le≈øs ≈øides of the≈øe Planes are ≈øo placed alternately, that the 3 greater an≈øwer to the 3 le≈øs. About the≈øe are plac'd 6 Quadrangular Planes with unequal ≈øides and angles, the greater bending towards the Centre of the Chry≈øtal, and the le≈øs accordingly
How very unlike this is to the before-de≈øcrib'd Figure of the Purging Salt, may ea≈øily appear by compari≈øon.

Nor can this bitter Purging Salt with more Ju≈øtice be reckon'd among≈øt the Muriatick or common Salts, which well purify'd has a very different ta≈øt from the Purging Salt, and al≈øo from Allom; its Figure is likewi≈øe as different, for it ≈øhoots not long ways, but contracted almo≈øt in the form of a Cube.

Be≈øides, the Purging Salt calcin'd in a Crucible, with a ≈øtrong Fire, emits no vi≈øible vapour, nor lo≈øes more than half of its weight; but common Salt thus calcin'd, as 'tis much more fluid, ≈øo it a≈øcends in thick ≈ømoaky vapours, leaving ≈øcarce an 18th part of the whole in the Crucible.
Neither (which may ≈øeem ≈øtrange) does the Spirit of common Salt Di≈øtill'd, as the Spirit of the Purging Salt, coagulate Milk, unle≈øs added to it when 'tis Boiled.
To be certain of this, I try'd the following Experiment.

La≈øtly, In≈øtead of the Spirit of the Purging Salt, I us'd the Spirit of common Salt, and that much ≈øtronger than the former Spirit, in the ≈øame proportion and method, but the Milk remained fluid in its Natural ≈øtate without any coagulation.

div.head: CHAP. V. The difference of the bitter Purging Salt from Nitrous and Calcarious Salts.
div.p: NOR does this Salt differ le≈øs from all kinds of Nitrous Salts; from which, by its bitter ta≈øt alone, its enough di≈øtingui≈øh'd.

Nor le≈øs by its Figure, for the Chry≈øtals of Nitre ≈øhoot not into four corner'd Parallel Planes, but always into ≈øix; nor into right Angles, but obtu≈øe, and their tops ≈øeldom terminate in 4 ≈øloping Planes, but mo≈øtly in 2, and ≈øometimes in 6, and tho≈øe more equal than in the Purging bitter Salt.
The Purging bitter Salt thrown into the Fire is not at all inflamable but Nitre burns with a bright flame and roaring noi≈øe, till the mo≈øt part of it evaporates.

I have ≈øaid the mo≈øt part of it, nor do I retract my a≈ø≈øertion, for in the 3d Chapter we have ob≈øerv'd about a 20th part to remain after the deflagration, which is in no wi≈øe Nitrous, but Lixivial, from Wood-A≈øhes mix'd with it by the Nitre-Makers.

But further, the bitter Salt in a Spoon, held over the flame of a Candle, will melt
in a moment, and bubble up as if thrown in to the fire; but Nitre, with ≈øuch a heat; will ≈øcarcely melt, but take up at lea≈øt 8 times the ≈øpace of the other, and emits a mo≈øt re≈øplendent flame.

On the contrary, tho' Nitre melts with difficulty, 'tis when melted much more fluid, for in a Crucible, in a ≈øtrong fire, it boils not like Allom, or the bitter Salt, but flows like Ro≈øin or melted Metals.
From Nitre melted in a Crucible ari≈øe thick Exhalations, which you never ≈øee from the bitter Salt, tho' in the ≈øtronge≈øt Fire.
Add likewi≈øe, that they differ from one another in their power of coagulating Milk.
For half a Dram of the Purging Salt, thrown into half a Pint of Milk, will turn it very gray; but Nitre mix'd after the ≈øame manner, tho' in much greater proportion, has no ≈øuch effect.

The ≈øolubility of Nitre, as we have before prov'd, is two parts in three le≈øs than the Purging Salt, for half an Ounce of common Water will, in the Winter, by agitation and a warm hand, di≈ø≈øolve not above a Dram and half of Nitre.
Its gravity is likewi≈øe very different, which appears by the following Experiment.

I put Oil of Turpentine into a Cylindar to the height of 3 Fingers; I then put in two Ounces of the Purging Salt, which rais'd the Oil a Finger higher, but from an equal weight of depurated Nitre, the Oil was elevated not higher than 3 fourths of a Finger; therefore the bitter Purging Salt is a 4th part lighter than Nitre.
But Water impregnated with the Purging Salt occupies a le≈øs ≈øpace, its bulk con≈øidered, than the ≈øame quantity with as much Sal Nitri di≈ø≈øolved in it.
That is, Water in≈øtead of Oil mix'd with the Salts in a Vial; when they are di≈ø≈øolv'd, the former ≈øub≈øides lower than the latter.

La≈øtly, I Di≈øtill'd Dantzick Vitriol, Sal Armoniack, and a like quantity of the bitter Salt, in≈øtead of Nitre, in order to make the Aqua Regia. Now if this had been a Nitrous Salt, this Water wou'd, like Aqua Regia, have di≈ø≈øolv'd Gold, but we could find no ≈øuch power in this Water.

Nor is it the Nitre of the Ancients, for 'tis nothing like that of the Egyptians ≈øo often mention'd by Hypocrates; ≈øomething like which is de≈øcrib'd by Dio≈øcorides and Pliny to be of a purple colour and biting; nor that of Etius, like Earth calcin'd and quench'd with Wine.
Nor, la≈øtly, can it be reckon'd with the Sal Calcarius; for the Purging Salt, or Water only, coagulates Milk with a much harder Curd, and greater plenty of Serum, than the Lime Water will.
And, if that Power of Coagulation were equal, how many Liquors have we mention'd that curdle Milk, which are neither Calcarious nor Aluminous.

Spirit of Nitre, dropt into the Cream that ≈øwims atop of the Lime-Water, or upon Lime it ≈øelf, will cau≈øe a vi≈øible Ebullition; but the ≈øame Spirit will have no ≈øuch Effect upon the Purging Salt.
There can be no where more difference in the ta≈øte of Things, than between the Purging Salt and the Calcarious; for the one is Lixivial and Sweet; the other, as it were Cold and Bitter.

Lime will, by pouring a little Water upon it, pre≈øently fall to Powder. On the contrary, the Calx of the Purging Salt powder'd, will, by the ≈øame means, run immediately into a hard Sub≈øtance, and in a few Moments be like a Stone.

Lamb's-Conduit Water, mixt with Lime-Water, will in a very little time grow white, with a dark clowdy Curdling; as it will with the Purging Waters:
But, if you mix it with Water impregnated with the Calx of the Purging Salt, no Muddine≈øs nor Colour will follow.

Common Water impregnated with this Salt, and afterwards evaporated, will re≈øtore you the whole quantity you di≈ø≈øolv'd, without any wa≈øte; but Lime-Water evaporated, the Salt is for the mo≈øt part tran≈ømuted into a ≈øtony and ta≈øtle≈øs Sub≈øtance: The Cau≈øe of which is, that the Saline Parts of the Aqu. Calcis do ≈øo intimately imbrace and unite with any other Aerial Salt, that they make a third Nurtral Salt; as in Oil of Ani≈ø≈øeeds and Vitriol, ≈øhaken together, you have a Refine, properly ≈øo call'd, which, if you wa≈øh, will yield you no manner of ta≈øte.

This may be illu≈øtrated by the following Experiment. I kept Lime-Water in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt with a Cork, and as much in an open Ve≈ø≈øel, for a Week or longer; that in the ≈øtopt Vial had no Cream upon it; but that in the open Ve≈ø≈øel where the Air could freely arrive at the Water, was cover'd with an in≈øipid and ≈øtony Cream.

But Water, in which the Purging Salt is di≈ø≈øolv'd, kept in an open Ve≈ø≈øel, and
many Days expos'd to the Air, will have no Cream at all on its ≈øurface: And that which appears in boiling the Purging Waters, is not in the lea≈øt Calcarious, as we have formerly prov'd.

Add al≈øo the very different ≈øolubility of the≈øe Salts; for half an Ounce of the Bitter Purging Salt will be ea≈øily, and without Heat or much Agitation pre≈øently di≈ø≈øolv'd in ≈øix times its quantity of Water. But to the di≈ø≈øolution of ≈øo much of the Calcarious Salt, is required two Gallons and a half of Water, which is 640 times its weight. For ≈øo much common Water is nece≈ø≈øary to edulcorate an Ounce of Calx Vivens; which done, there remains in the bottom of the Ve≈ø≈øel about half an Ounce of pure white and In≈øipid Calx.

But the Bitter Purging Salt is eminently di≈øtingui≈øh'd from the fore-mention'd (if there were no other way) by its Medicinal Virtues, as we ≈øhall evidently demon≈øtrate, in the latter Part of this Tract, where we ≈øpeak of its U≈øe.

In the mean time, we do not deny a ≈ømall Portion, as well of Nitre and common Salt, as of a ≈øtony Sub≈øtance, may be contained, not only in the Purging Waters, but even in the Salt it ≈øelf. And,
indeed, 'tis probable that no Body, exi≈øtent in Nature, is purely ≈øimple. Silver, every one knows, is mixt with Copper or Lead; Gold, with Silver in the ≈øame Mine Vein; nay, and Metallick Ma≈øs: But it does not follow, that Silver and Copper, or Gold and Silver, do hereby con≈øtitute a third Species; but the two, or more, ≈øeparable Metals exi≈øt together.

Nor, can we inferr an Identity of Bodies from their agreement in ≈øome qualities; for Lead and Gold do ≈øo agree; both are ≈øolid, opacque, ductile, fu≈øible, heavy Bodies, &c. and therefore are both Metals; but nothing is Gold, that has not all the qualities of Gold.
For Gold does not differ more ways, nor in a more eminent manner from Lead, than the Bitter Purging Salt is di≈øtingui≈øh'd from all other Salts; and therefore is in its own Nature the mo≈øt Noble.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Some additional Ob≈øervations of the Nature of the Bitter Purging Salt.
div.p: THE mo≈øt ≈øpecial Qualities of this Salt, that we have already de≈øcrib'd, are a ta≈øte gently and almo≈øt ≈øimply Bitter; and of all ≈øorts, that we know, mo≈øt re≈øembling the Cry≈øtals of Silver in ≈øimilitude of Ta≈øte. For the≈øe, indeed, are bitter, but very much ≈øo, and not without ≈øome Au≈øterity joined with it.

I have in another place ob≈øerv'd the Lapis Calaminaris to have ≈øome Qualities common with Silver, therefore I dropp'd into the Powder of this Stone ≈øome drops of Spirit of Nitre; and the fermentation over, I wa≈øh'd the mixture with common Water. This Water, like the Chry≈øtals of Silver, is not only very ≈øtyptick but bitter, and is the only bitter Mineral that I know of, except the Salt of Luna, and the Purging Salt. But whether the Purging Salt do ari≈øe from any Silver Minera, wholly or in part ≈øo, or from the Lapis Calaminaris, or rather from any other, I leave undetermined, being never able to get any of the true Minera of this Salt.
But this is very plain from the forementioned Experiments, that the Bitter Purging Salt is compounded of ≈øome parts in their nature Acid, and others Alkaline, and a little Lixivial.
In Salts compounded of various Principles, the Proportion, the Nature and the Union of tho≈øe Principles are to be con≈øider'd.
Some Acid Particles are frequently found in Lixivial Salts, but in a ≈ømall proportion.
But in Tartar, which is the Salt of Wine, the Saline Parts are much le≈ø≈øer than the Acid, which exi≈øt in a much greater proportion.
And 'tis almo≈øt the ≈øame in the Bitter Purging Salt, with this difference only, That in the former the Acids are actually mix'd with the Alkaline, but in the latter Potentially.
Moreover, all Lixivial Salts are Acrimonious, but tho≈øe commonly call'd Te≈øtaceous are not without rea≈øon accounted the more gentle.
As likewi≈øe are ≈øome Acid Liquors, ≈øuch as the Juice of Wood-Sorrel, a Di≈ø≈øolution of the Cream of Tartar, &c. but the Purging Salt is gentler than any of the≈øe.
Indeed, by Di≈øtillation it gives an Acid Spirit, but this Acid Ta≈øte is not perceptible till its Principles are intimately di≈ø≈øolv'd and divided by a mo≈øt violent Fire.
For the Salt it ≈øelf has neither Acrimony nor Acidity.
Nor is it Ta≈øtle≈øs, but very ≈øubtle and biting, and therefore a mo≈øt Efficacious Medicine.

Its Admirable Subtilty will appear by its penetrating any Earthen Ve≈ø≈øel, if not very well Glaz'd about the bottom; of which, on the out≈øide, there will be a woolly or hoary Concretion in colour like an Amethy≈øt.

The Principles of this Salt are al≈øo more clo≈øely united than in Tartar, and afford many other Remedies. For the Union is ≈øo firm, that one of its parts, viz. its Acid, cannot be above the one half of it ≈øeparated from the other, and that not without a reverberatory Fire. Whence 'tis, that when other gentle Purges frequently elude the Phy≈øicians expectation, this does very ≈øeldom or never deceive him.

For ≈øuch Medicines do work mo≈øt upon the Humours of the Body, which are lea≈øt alterable by tho≈øe Humours: In
the number of which this Salt, and other Minerals, are to be accounted.

La≈øt of all; This Salt, tho' it does con≈øi≈øt of different Principles, is very pure, if rightly and diligently prepar'd; in≈øomuch that it does not retain the thou≈øandth part of any extraneous Body with it ≈øelf.

For, if you evaporate de≈øtill'd Water, impregnated with an Ounce of this Salt, 'twill yield not a Particle of any Heterogeneous Salt, ≈øtony Sediment, or Cremor, but the very ≈øame Ounce of mo≈øt pure Salt.

div.head: Part the Second. OF THE USE OF THE Bitter Purging Salt.
CHAP. I. Of the more General U≈øe of the Bitter Purging Salt.
div.p: THE U≈øe of the Purging Waters of Ep≈øom, &c. is ≈øo excellent and manifold, and ≈øo very well known to London Phy≈øicians, that no Body can doubt of it.

For in many grievous Di≈øea≈øes, Experience has prov'd 'em a mo≈øt efficacious Remedy, endued with no unwhol≈øom Quality; which, rationally pre≈øcrib'd, I

One Objection there is brought again≈øt the≈øe Waters, with ≈øome ≈øhew of Rea≈øon; 'tis, That the Waters in boiling ≈øeparate a ≈øtony Cremor: From whence we may fear a Matter may be ≈øupply'd, fit to generate the Stone in the Body.

This Objection is an≈øwer'd by two Experiments; one before-mention'd; and the Second drawn from Phy≈øical Ob≈øervations. For 'tis plain, from what we have before prov'd, That this ≈øtony Cremor does not ari≈øe upon the Purging Waters, nor upon Aqua Calcis, unle≈øs expos'd to the Air, and in an open Ve≈ø≈øel; and therefore no ≈øtony Sub≈øtance can be generated by the Waters in the Body.

But, ≈øay they, the Air is mixt with the Humours of the Body. We grant it; and likewi≈øe with Waters; as may be demon≈øtrated by the Air Pump. And this Lime-Waterm, which ≈øo ≈øuddenly proceduces a stony Sub≈øtance by the admi≈ø≈øion of the Air, is frequently and ≈øafely given by phy≈øicians. And our Sugar-Refiner u≈øe it in the purifying their Sugar; by which means the Treacle is better ≈øeperated from the concre≈øcible part; and it acquires a greater finene≈øs and whiltene≈øs.

But, if the Purging Water is a good Medicine, how much more is the Salt to be accounted ≈øo? For, if we ≈øhould, for Arguments ≈øake, grant what is objected again≈øt the Waters; yet that will make not at all again≈øt the Salt, depurated from its ≈øtony Sub≈øtance.

Moreover, if the Water you take do abound with plenty of the Muriatick Salt, ≈øometimes it may Purge too violently; but the purified Salt, which is freed from it, is of all Purging Medicines the mo≈øt gentle.

But ≈øome, I fore≈øee, will Que≈øtion the whol≈øomne≈øs of this Salt, from the Acid Spirit it yields in Di≈øtillation; but this Objection does as much oppo≈øe the U≈øe of the Water, as of the Salt contained in them: For the ≈øame Rea≈øon, we may as well pretend to leave off the U≈øe of Honey, Sugar, or White-Bread; every one of which, by the help of Fire, will yield a Di≈øtill'd Spirit violently Acid and Biting.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Method of pre≈øcribing the Bitter Purging Salt.
div.p: THis Salt may be taken Di≈ø≈øolv'd in any Vehicle agreeable to the Palate, or grateful to the Ta≈øte of the Patient; ≈øuch as Spring-Waters, Barley-Water, Water-Gruel, Po≈ø≈øet-Drink, Whey, &c. I do mo≈øt commonly pre≈øcribe common Water Boil'd, and Aromatiz'd with a little Mace, to two, three, or four Pints; of which I add half an Ounce, or an Ounce, or a greater Do≈øe of the Salt. div.head: CHAP. III. Of the more particular U≈øe of this Salt, and fir≈øt of all of its U≈øe in Di≈øea≈øes of the Ventricle.
div.p: WHat I ≈øhall now in≈øert of the Purging-Waters and their Salt, is not from uncertain conjectures, but is demon≈øtrable by the daily Experience of other Learned Men as well as my own; all whom have us'd both the Salt and the Water, in the following Di≈øea≈øes, with happy ≈øucce≈øs.

And fir≈øt of all, this Purging-Water, or its Salt, is a mo≈øt Amicable Medicine to the Stomach, exciting an Appetite, and promoting a good Dige≈øtion; which it does partly by its Acid Principle, partly by the bitterne≈øs of the whole, or its Alkaline Mixture.

But chiefly from the former, becau≈øe it affords a Spirit in ≈øome ≈øort Analagous to the Spirit of the Salt, with which all Meats are ≈øea≈øon'd; and al≈øo from the latter, for we do every day Experience the Stomach to be ≈øtrengthned by this, and mo≈øt other Bitters. 'Tis al≈øo well known, that the
Appetite is chiefly ≈øtrengthned by the U≈øe of Compound Salts, for almo≈øt all Pickles are prepar'd not with Salts alone, but with Salt and Vinegar. French Red-Wine we allow to be very whol≈øom with our Food, becau≈øe of its Tartarous Salt, of all others, the mo≈øt Compound; and Salt of Steel, a very Compound Salt, is as Famous among Stomach-Medicines.

Therefore while there is the Natural proportion of either Salt in the Stomach, Concoction is duly performed, but when either prevail, ≈øometimes the Acid, ≈øometimes the Alkaline, are nece≈ø≈øary to re≈øtore it to its Office.

for the quieting which, the Bitter Purging Salt, or Waters, is a mo≈øt excellent Remedy, for the ≈øame rea≈øon that the Salt of Wormwood, and Juice of Lemons, is ≈øo Famous, tho' this Salt is highly preferrable to it, with one ≈øtroke de≈øtroying and carrying off the Peccant Salts.
Al≈øo in the Cardialgia, or Heart-burning, and other pains of that kind, no Medicines can be more ≈øafe and efficacious, nor in a hot Hypocondriack Di≈øpo≈øition.

In the fore-mentioned Ca≈øes, I have ≈øometimes pre≈øcribed the Purging Waters, or Salt, without any other Medicine, but more often with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of other Remedies, as Bleeding, Vomiting, and the like; for 'tis not the part of a prudent Phy≈øician, in dangerous Di≈øea≈øes, to tru≈øt his Patients Health, and his own Reputation, to one only Medicine, tho' never ≈øo Famous.

div.head: For a lo≈øt Appetite.
div.p:
